The tree is located on a property adjacent to Sayward Road, which is the access road between Highway 19 and the Village of Sayward.  Sayward is located on North-central Vancouver Island, about 80 km North-west of Campbell River. When driving from Campbell River, proceed North on Highway 19 to the intersection with Sayward Rd. tree_site_notes: The tree appears to be healthy.  It has four main trunks, all approximately the same size.  This past winter, a large number of medium-sized branched were broken off due to the abnormally high snowfall. The tree is located on one corner of a cleared field.  The surrounding growth is sparse mixed deciduous and conifer, with most of the Alders logged off 3 to 4 years ago.

access_notes: From South Shore Road in Lake Cowichan, turn onto Cowichan Lake Road towards Duncan. Follow for 2.2km until there is a private driveway on the right side of the road across from a solitary new home on the right side of the road (as of Dec. 2022). Keep going another 100m and there will be a short connector trail from Cowichan Lake Road to the Cowichan Valley trail. The Lumpkin is just off the far side of Cowichan Valley Trail in a small clearing.
tree_site_notes: The Lumpkin is a beautiful, limby maple with a thick, burly trunk that is completely coated in lichens and bryophytes. Standing as it does in a clearing allows a full view of the tree from the trail, even when fully leafed out.

access_notes: Take Highway 18 from Duncan towards Lake Cowichan. Pull off on the north side of the road just before the fire hazard sign. A short scramble up the roadcut leads to gentle terrain, with a 200m hike through a second growth alder and maple forest opening up into a remnant patch of old growth along a seasonal creek. Several large firs >1m in diameter are scattered within a younger cohort of firs, redcedars, and maples.
tree_site_notes: The Bushcamp Maple is a large tree standing near the edge of the old growth here, amongst some western redcedars. The large, branching crowns gives this tree a broad stem.

access_notes: Exiting off of Highway 19A onto Terrain Road, take your first right onto Regent Road. Continue on Regent Road, until you pass over the bridge going over the Oyster River. Once over the bridge, the trail you want to be on is direclty to the left. It is wide and easily seen from the road. There is a small pull out that can be parked on. Across from the streeet (by the telephone pole) there is an older trail sign. You do not want to go down this trail, but that is an indication you are in the correct area. Starting down the trail (on the left), walk for a mere 1-2 minutes and this large black cottonwood will be on your left hand side.
tree_site_notes: The overall health of the tree is excellent with crown and stem intact. Lots of shrubbery below the tree, and it has a very even, continuous, tall stem. It is very noticiable, and stands out amongst other, smaller trees nearby. The ground is very flat.

Starting down the trail (on the left), walk for 1-2 minutes and the first large black cottonwood will be on your left hand side (tree # 1174). This tree is just a little further, also on the left. It is a bit further off the trail than the first, but its crown is very visible and it does stick out quite a bit amongst the other trees!
tree_site_notes: Overall, the tree seems to be in good health. It is quite tall, and has a huge canopy. The slope is completely flat.

access_notes: From Highway 19A turn onto Glenmore Road. Continue on Glenmore until you reach the Oyster River Nature Park parking lot. The tree is located only a few metres from the trail as you enter the Oyster River Nature Park from the bottom parking lot near the old Fishermens Lodge Pub. It is on the left hand side of the trail and is very noticable.
tree_site_notes: The tree has an extremely columnar trunk with no noticeable taper until the first branching at approxumately 25-30m. The tree appears to be in good health with a nearly symmetrical radial crown. There is what appears to be a small 15-20cm diameter secondary trunk originating near the base of the tree that has self-grafted to the vastly larger main trunk. It has been completely incorporated intomthe main stem and cannot be differentiated beyind the 8-10m height on the mainstem. I would consider it to be an integral part of the tree. The tree appears to be in very good health with no broken limbs or apparent cavities in the main stem.

Go aproximately 1km on the Sutton Main until you will see the top of the tree above the advanced regen on the south low side of the road.
tree_site_notes:
Tree is showing sings of crown die back due to extreme age. It is growing on flat ground on high bench flood plain above the Nimpkish River near the junction of Sutton Creek and the Kla-anch wetlands. The area has high Elk useage.  The stand is very unique upper valley, CWHmm1 Amabilis dominant stand with multiple Amabalis well over 65m in height and we believed at least 2 may be taller than this nomination, but it is difficult to get the height of the others due to the heavy understory and brush.

The tallest tree previously measured adjacent to these, but now logged, was 248 ft tall. Because of this previously biggest trees loss, Chris Bowden-Green approached John Deal of Canfor to protect the remaining large Balsam within a proposed Elk Winter Range, due to its uniqueness as one of the last remaining old growth valley bottom Amabalis stands.

access_notes: Take Hiway 4 west from Port Alberni. Drive approximately 80km to the Maggie Lake FSR. Turn left and follow Maggie FSR for 11km to Macoah Villagfe turn-off. Keep left on Maggie FSR and drive another 4km to the end of Maggie FSR. Keep left and you are now on Toquaht FSR. Drive 9km to the junction with Lucky FSR. Turn right onto Lucky FSR and drive 2.5km to the junction with Black Peaks FSR. Keep left and follow Lucky FSR for another 2.4km. You will pass two lakes on your right. The second (and larger lake is Kite Lake). Once past Kite Lake, you will come to a major junction. Keep right and continue along Lucky FSR for another 1.4km. there will be a deactivated and brushed in spur road on your right. This is the start of teh rough trail up to Block F004C4DT. Hike up the spur for 700m to a very overgorwn junction. Keep to the left and hike a further 450 m. You will come across some yellow flagging that indicates a rough trail up to F004C4DT. The trail heads upslope from the spur road and is heavy going through an advanced plantation for approximately 150m. Once you reach the Old-growth it is easy but steep hiking. From the end of the flagged trail, continue up slope heading directly south for approximately 170m until you reach the upper falling boundary. The Amabilis fir (5 trees) will be visible both ahead of you and slightly to the right. To reach Cypress, continue angling upslope in a southeasterly direction along the base of the steep rock outcops. You will find C4DT-002 after hiking/climbing for 350m. Tree C4DT is approximately 145m above the first Cypress. Follow the rock bluff uphill (keeping the gully to your left). C4DT-001 is approximately 150m upslope and is situated on a rock knob in a nice open area of timber.
tree_site_notes: C4DT-006 is located in the CWHvm2(01) and is situated mid-slope. The slope (50%) has a N aspect.

1. km 0.0 - start at the Port Renfrew Community Center/Fire

6. After crossing the bridge keep on the Gordon River Main
for about 1.5 km, staying to the RIGHT at the next “Y”.
7. Shortly after you will cross a small bridge over a creek

8. Continue past the Avatar Grove on the Gordon River Main
for approximately 4.5 km and take your FIRST RIGHT onto

balance.
tree_site_notes: The tree stands alone in a clearcut from 2012 and is hard to miss. Turn right onto Nahmint Main and drive 1.2km to the bridge crossing the Nahmint River. Once across the one-lane bridge, drive 0.2km to the junction with Riverside Main. Turn left onto Riverside Main and drive 1.7km to Block 1513 located on the west side of the road. If you drive past a small weedy lake to your right, you have driven past Block 1513 and the tree. There is a small road on your right just past the lake which makes a convenient turnaround. The tree is very visible along the skyline beyond the southern boundary of Block 1513. There is a rough trail from the road (approximately 20m past the southern falling boundary of the block that leads up to 1513-002. You will pass a large Western Redcedar (Legacy Tree 1513-001, 3.15m in diameter or 9.9m in circumference) as you climb the slope up to 1513-002. There is another large Western Redcedar (Legacy Tree 1513-003, 3.11m in diameter or 9.8m in circumference) located approximately 25m up slope of 1513-002. All trees are marked with bright yellow BCTS Legacy Tree plaques. Use caution when traveling on gravel Forest Service roads. These are active industrial roads and expect to meet large vehicles at any time!
tree_site_notes: 1513-002 is a Douglas-fir in good health. There are no apparent signs of rot present upon a visual inspection of the tree. The tree is largely intact with only a few small broken limbs present in the upper portion of the canopy. there are several moderate-sized burls (approximately 1m across and flattened) on the up-slope side of the tree. It is located within the CWH vm1 and is situated on a small bench located on the lower slope with a NE aspect. The tree can be considered to be windfirm as it is sheltered within a 12.1 hectare Old Growth Management Area. This OGMA contains several other Legacy Trees (two Western Redcedar; 1513-001 and 1513-003).There is minimal evidence of historic windthrow in the vicinity of 1513-002 or throughout the OGMA.

From the small town of Youbou, on the Eastern end of Lake Cowichan, head Westward on the North Shore Road,

Follow Flora until you reach Upper Klanawa Main ( 48.861963, -124.739748 ) and turn left.
Not long after passing Newstead Main (do not take this road), the road starts climbing and splits. Take the left spur
K-265, up a steep pitch and around a tight bend ( 48.8267934, -124.7812745 ). After some time, along the South side

48.7969942, -124.8668236 ). This is where the Main and East Forks of the Klanawa River meet. This new road
bends East and becomes very coarse. It is advised that one parks in a safe location and walks to the Bumblebee
Tree from the road (starting at 48.801119, -124.832387 ).
*Alternatively the Hummingbird and adjacent forest stands can be reached by crossing one of the numerous log-jams
on the Klanawa River East Fork. Park on Newstead Main , and find a log-jam that you can cross safely ( 48.799488,
-124.817626 ) or ( 48.802287, -124.808875 ) for example. Be sensible, do not attempt when the river is flowing high,
and no I am not responsible if your shoe soles are slippery and your iphone goes for a swim ;) Keep your electronics
safe in a ziplock or wet bag. Personally, we prefer using Newstead Main, the road is in better condition and it is a
more straightforward route.
Please be advised that this is an ACTIVE logging area, follow suitably safe driving techniques and be vigilant and
courteous to other road users. It is advised to only visit this area on weekends when logging activities are minimal.
This is a remote area without cellular reception so plan your trip accordingly. Input your coordinates before you leave
home. In general the gravel road driving is reasonable for most vehicles, but fill your tank and definitely bring a full
sized spare tire along for this trip.

From the small town of Youbou, head Westward on the North Shore Road, following along the shore of Cowichan
Lake. Arrive at a signposted split between Bamfield and Nitinat and head left towards Nitinat. Driving past the head
of the Lake, you eventually enter the Nitinat River Valley. At the entrance of Nitinat River Ecological Preserve
(Eastern Portion 48.901189, -124.545689 ) you will encounter old-growth Douglas fir forest and some roadside
CMT’s. Have a look at the impressive Nitinat Fir (just below the road, 48.893787, -124.556285 ).
It is also worth checking out the canyon section of the Nitinat river ( 48.895723, -124.558131 ).
A couple of hundred meters past the turnoff for Granite Main, find a safe place to park. On foot, follow an old spur on
the north side of the road ( 48.876268, -124.587473 ) briefly. When the spur becomes overgrown, head left
( 48.878611, -124.585422 ) through the bush. Heading slightly downhill, start contouring to your right along the hillside
until you encounter an impressive stand of Fir and Hemlock on the slope above the river. Here you will encounter the
Cauliflower Mushroom Fir. Follow the lower slope around a corner (northward and upstream) for 50m or so, staying
above the dense brush along the river edge. Once you can easily cross onto the river flats, find your way to the river
edge and safely fjord across the river, just above the bend. You should be able to see a large spruce and you may be
able to see 3PP’s double leaders a little further back from the shore. The tree is located on the flats about 60m from
shore amongst sword ferns.
Please be advised that this is an ACTIVE logging area, follow suitably safe driving techniques and be vigilant and
courteous to other road users. It is advised to only visit this area on weekends when logging activities are minimal.
This is a remote region without cellular reception so plan your trip accordingly. Input your coordinates before you
leave home. In general the gravel road driving is reasonable for most vehicles, but fill your tank and definitely bring a
full sized spare tire along for this trip. There are some basic amenities available in the Village of Nitinat. Only cross
the river when the flow is low, it is recommended to have your electronics in watertight bags and please be careful.
tree_site_notes:
Gradually tapering and with a distinctive burl, the trunk splits into two healthy looking upward facing
leaders at approximately the 40m mark.
Located on a flat and sandy riparian floodplain, 3PP is a fine Douglas fir standing amidst Bigleaf
Maple, Hemlock and Sitka spruce about 60m from the bank of the Nitinat River.
This floodplain is part of a series of high quality, intact riverside patches of old growth standing
between the Eastern and Western portions of the Nitinat River Ecological Reserves. Sitka Spruce begin to
Reach full potential in the floodplains and Douglas fir become less abundant at river level. Here and across
the river in Macoola Grove, one will find the Red Listed Tooth- leaved Monkey flowers and Blue Listed
Scouler’s corydalis carpeting the floor during the late spring and summer.
For more detailed information about the trees of the Central Nitinat River and the Macoola Grove region
visit the Vancouver Island Prominent Tree Survey, a project hosted by the coastaltrailcollective.com

access_notes: Public access is permitted, but summer vehicular access is controlled at a gate. Trail access is open all summer. Winter access is restricted to clients.  From Fernie, on Highway #3 turn onto Mount Fernie Park Road, proceed through campground to the Island Lake parking lot (gate is sometimes closed so inquire about vehicle accessibility). If able to drive to the lodge, drive the 8 km through spectacular old growth cedar forest, then follow the Fir Trail and look for the large western larch on the crest. From this vantage point, peering down into the deep gully this very stately tree is visible, but very difficult to access. Alternatively, book yourself a cat skiing adventure, and ask to be taken to Hunter Bowl, where the snowcat pick up zone is located very close to the tree.
tree_site_notes:
This remarkable tree stands alone in an alder slide path, where evidence of seepage on the adjacent southerly facing slope was observed, as there was no snow on this slope. There are many very large trees on the crest above this Engelmann spruce, including western larch, Douglas fir, and some other mature spruce.
The tree appears to be in good health, as a 400 mm increment bore core sample was extracted with no signs of internal decay. The tree supports a healthy crown, and given its sheltered location, will hopefully extend its longevity for a while yet. Age is estimated at 550 years old.
Summer access would be very difficult as a waterfall is directly below, an alder choked gully above, and very thick vegetation surrounding the tree. Access at the time of measurement was via snowmobile. The Fir Trail is located above the tree, so further summer site access investigation is warranted.

tree_site_notes: The tree is located at the base of a moderate west facing slope in a relatively flat area.  The tree is in good health and does not appear to have a broken top.  A good view of the top of the tree is difficult due to the surrounding Ponderosa pine and Douglas-fir trees, which partially block the view. The area is used by mountain bike and hiking enthusiasts.  In general, the area is characterized by steep rocky bluffs and flat benches.  The larger trees tend to grow on the benches or in ravines where moisture is more plentiful.  The area is used by whitetail deer, elk, black bear and coyote, as well as numerous species of birds.

tree_site_notes: This spruce is absolutely phenominal and perhaps now the largest known overall in the Carmanah Valley. I boasts a thick, towering trunk that puts it in a league and likely age class of its own compared to other large spruce trees in the area. It also has one of the most dynamic and sprawling canopies. The main trunk breaks into two main stems which then also have multiple iterations of their own. From a top down perspective, the canopy of this one tree appears to be of 3-4 individual trees. This is one of the most rewarding and noteworthy big tree finds in a long time.

access_notes: Located within Gwaii Haanas National Park Reserve and Haida Heritage Site is the ancient village, and now current watchmen of Windy Bay, or Hlk'yah GaawGa. Windy Bay is on the western side of Lyell Island, and is home to a moderately sized salmon bearing stream and estuary.  From the watchmen cabin (south side of river), there is a well marked and maintained trail that follows the estuary up to the foot of the river, and crosses the river to the north side. From this point the trail winds into the woods, where you will walk for about ten minutes, before encountering the spruce tree right on the trail.

From the small town of Youbou, on the Eastern end of Lake Cowichan, head Westward on the North Shore Road, continuing all the way past the lake on Cowichan Main and eventually following the Nitinat River.Turn right at T-Intersection ( 48.8627379, -124.6438995 ) over the bridge which crosses Nitinat River, following
Carmanah Main. A visit to the waterfalls on the Little Nitinat Falls is recommended for a quick break (unmarked pull off near 48.871476, -124.687404 ). Follow Carmanah Main until a bridge on your left crosses the Little Nitinat River onto Flora Main ( 48.8994754, -124.6887141 ). Follow Flora until you reach Upper Klanawa Main ( 48.861963, -124.739748 ) and turn left. Not long after passing Newstead Main (do not take this road), the road starts climbing and splits. Take the left spur K-265, up a steep pitch and around a tight bend ( 48.8267934, -124.7812745 ). After some time, along the South side of K-265 there are a couple of small lakes accessed via a short spur (approx 48.8274633, -1248130282 ), where one can visit the Fairy Bell Cedar at Dorothy Lake (at the head of the second lake, 48.825688, -124.822826 ).
Coming to another T-Intersection ( 48.8307925, -124.8372049 ), turn left and continue straight past another
intersection and follow it until you reach the spruce flats and recently logged areas at the bottom of the valley (approx
48.7969942, -124.8668236 ). This is where the Main and East Forks of the Klanawa River meet. This new road
bends East and becomes very coarse. It is advised that one parks in a safe location and walks into Hummingbird
Grove (starting at 48.801119, -124.832387 ).
Please be advised that this is an ACTIVE logging area, follow suitably safe driving techniques and be vigilant and
courteous to other road users. It is advised to only visit this area on weekends when logging activities are minimal.
This is a remote area without cellular reception so plan your trip accordingly. Input your coordinates before you leave
home. In general the gravel road driving is reasonable for most vehicles, but fill your tank and definitely bring a full
sized spare tire along for this trip.
tree_site_notes: CWHvh1 07. Hummingbird Tree has large buttressing roots, numerous large burls, a bare crown and a healthy canopy. The Tree is located on a toe slope, in a recent cutblock, situated near the edge of a riparian plain. It stands on the North Bank of the East Fork of the Klanawa River. Ther are numerous fine and large specimens of Sitka spruce, western redcear and even occasional Douglas fir still stands in the Klanawa River Valley System. Hummingbird Grove is one of the two outstanding spruce groves of this beautiful area. For more detailed information about the trees of this region visit the Vancouver Island Prominent Tree Survey, a project hosted by the coastaltrailcollective.com

tree_site_notes: Touted as the "Cathedral Grove of the North“. The western redcedar, tree #1293, is upstream, off trail, through some flat, but deadfall barriered ground.  The Sitka spruce, tree #1294, is very close to the western redcedar.

tree_site_notes: A beautiful Sitka spruce tree growing in a Wildlife Habitat Area along the Keith River near Side Bay. Legend has it loggers refused to cut down this patch of forest given it's impressive nature while the entire surrounding areas were clearcut in the 1980's. Today an island of old-growth exists here. Impressive Sitka spruce trees abound in this grove, which is braided by a network of clear streams and wildlife trails. Still more to explore!

The stumps in the second-growth nearby tell a heartbreaking story of trees of almost unimanginable proportions and densities, sadly gone forever. The Spruce Bay Trail is a glimpse into that lost world.

access_notes: A short bushwhack off of San Joseph Main through some wet and bushy terrain.
tree_site_notes: A towering Sitka spruce with two branches shooting upwards off its side like someone putting there arms up in the air!

access_notes: Starting from Holberg, take San Joseph Main towards the coast. Turn left onto Raft Main. Take your first right onto a small side road (semi-over grown with alders). A short ways down you will see the current #1 Sitka spruce tree on your right. Park here and admire that tree before walking further down the road. You will see a ribbon of trees on the left combing close to the road, parallel this towards the back edge of the clearing where you will find this tree.
tree_site_notes: CWHvh1 06 A big ole' Sitka with some junk in its trunk! Big Girtha is just one of many massive spruce trees found in this exceptional zone - possibly the highest concentrations of giant Sitka's that we know of, largely (we think) due to the limestone substrate they grow on.

access_notes: Starting from Holberg get to NE Main and start travelling down Quatsino Sound. Carry onto SE Koprino Main then onto Hathaway Main then Michelson Main. Use GPS points to park close to the tree which will be on the left side of the road through a bit of a swampy section. Not super far but gumboots might help. You can see the big top from the road.
tree_site_notes: A beast of a spruce tree with a big burl at the base. This tree has a commanding presence when standing before it! Thankfully it's protected by an OGMA and WHA. There are other large spruce trees in the area. Worth more exploring in the dry season.

access_notes: Starting from Holberg get to NE Main and start travelling down Quatsino Sound. Carry onto SE Koprino Main then onto Hathaway Main then Michelson Main. Use GPS points to park close to the tree which will be on the left side of the road through a bit of a swampy section. Not super far but gumboots might help. You can see the big top from the road.
tree_site_notes: A nice big spruce in a nice forest. Thankfully it's protected by an OGMA and WHA. There is an amazing double-headed spruce across the road growing unprotected and well worth a look!
A nice spruce growing on a steep slope that leads down to the ocean in a far away forest. The hillside is home to additional spruce groves as well. Bit of a trek to get here.
I'd hope to find some nice big spruce here not far from Hecht Beach and Hecht Yeah we did!
A beautiful spruce with swirling base covered with golden moss. This is just one Sitka in a grove of a dozen or more that rivals what one might find in the Carmanah Valley.
A picture-perfect spruce covered with golden moss standing like a beacon in the ferny forest drawing you ever further in.
A big and beautiful spruce in a grove of other giants along the riverside. A trip back in time to see this stand. Thankfully it's protected within a Wildlife Habitat Area.

A noteable spruce with a flared base growing in a spectacular yet threatened grove. A beautiful creek flows through the middle of the forest here. Coastal temperate rainforest at its finest, but for how long…
A towering Sitka spruce growing along the Koprino River. Scurry down the slope to view the tree from below and you'll certainly be impressed! This tree is currently protected in an OGMA.
Another giant spruce growing along the Koprino River (there are a few if you look!) surrounded by a jungle of plants. And mosquitoes.
A spruce with a burly bottom in the splotchy sunlight of summer
A big lonely spruce left in a cutblock near Quatsino Sound. A stark reminder of the giants that were once found here.

A towering spruce pillar that makes a great roadside attraction for the wayward traveller. A short jaunt through a bit of bush takes you to this incredible tree which is stands out among the more even-aged hemlock forest surrounding it. A large gash near the base points to some troubled past that you'd have to ask its neighbours about to find out.
One of six big spruce left standing after logging. There is now five after one blew down. Will have to see if it survives as well…

access_notes: Victoria Main
tree_site_notes: Base of tree was very fluted, making Point of Germination determinations difficult.

access_notes: Along Hanna and Tintina Creeks, just east of Meziadin Lake. Tintina Creek is next to Bear Glacier Provincial Park.
tree_site_notes: In 1987 this tree was 210 years old and healthy.

access_notes: Along Hanna and Tintina Creeks, just east of Meziadin Lake
tree_site_notes: In 1987 this tree was 150+ years old with heart rot.

access_notes: Tree located approximately 100 m east of Dad's Run Ski Trail, approximately 100 m up slope from  Mom's Run Ski Trail.
tree_site_notes: Broken top. Tree has decay in trunk and is in poor condition although living.  Site aspect north, slope approximately 35-40%, middle slope, concave.

access_notes: Located at Fernie Alpine Resort, a person could ride the Elk Chair up (summer or winter) then walk up the summer road into the Lizard Bowl, where it wraps around to the top of the Ballet Run. Hidden in the alder behind a big larch tree is the subalpine fir.
tree_site_notes: There are many vey old subalpine fir growing in the Lizard Range. This particular tree has the benefit of being on a knob that is not subject to the many avalanches that course down either side. Also the big larch seems to have also afforded some protection. This tree is well hidden, and it is not until you climb underneath its branches to you gain the appreciation for how massive it is.

access_notes: From Tete Jaune Cache, drive east on Highway 5 / 16 for 3 kilometers towards Mount Robson. Park at pullout on south side of the highway just past truck weigh scale pullout. Cross the highway and find the trailhead for Little Lost Lake Recreation Site about 100m west of the pullout. There is a sign marking the trail. Hike up Little Lost Lake trail for about 1.8 km. Before reaching the lake, bushwack about 100m off the trail to reach the tree.
tree_site_notes: Tree is an outlier in a forest dominated by black cottonwood, white spruce, western red cedar, douglas fir and paper birch. Tree appears healthy with a large crown almost reaching the ground.

access_notes: The Olivia Creek Trail can be accessed by travelling up the Hartley Lake Rd. from Dicken Road. Hartley Lake Road is a narrow winding dirt road, but is passable under most conditions with a 2WD vehicle. Once you have passed the lake, below to the left, you are at the Hartley/Sulphur Creek Pass. Olivia Creek access is the second old road to the left, just before the road begins descending towards the Bull River. The old road can be quite overgrown, and will have large puddles to navigate around. This 4 km. road section can be driven in a 4WD if you are not worried about your paint job, and want to earn some more “Kootenay Pinstripes”. If you get lured into driving up this road, there are no good turn arounds until it can be too late. Using a bike, or hiking is recommended to get to the old sawdust pile, from where 1 km. further, on a less friendly road, connects you to the trailhead.
tree_site_notes:
The tree is a bit inconspicuous as a subalpine fir, as most of the surrounding trees are large Englemann spruce. The bark on this old tree was not easily distinguishable as a subalpine fir, but the branches swept right down close to the ground, allowing for tree species identification. Located on edge of an avalanche meadow, where a profusion of alpine flowers were in bloom, including: Sitka valerian, Forget-Me-Nots, stinging nettle, blue elderberry, clasping twisted stalk, yellow columbine, and silky phacelia. 
An adjacent 1.54 m. DBH Englemann Spruce was aged at 502 years old.

access_notes: Takla Lake is next to Mt. Blanchet Provincial Park. Km 85.5 driftwood FSR connector.
tree_site_notes: Healthy, conical form.

access_notes: Drive from the Argenta/Duncan Lake junction north up the Duncan FSR until arriving at the Glacier Creek FSR to the right. 29 km drive up the Glacier Creek FSR to trailhead parking area. 8.4 km trail with 653 m elevation gain. The tree is on a slope above the trail soon after you cross over a small bridge the big trees become visible up to the left.
tree_site_notes: Broken top with a rotted/unconstituted center, but appeared otherwise to be healthy. This is a gnarly tree.

access_notes: EC Manning Provincial Park. From Mount Frosty trail, descend talus to east of saddle before final climb to peak. Tree is located in open grove of larch below talus slopes, on bluffy terrain.
tree_site_notes: Aspect east, slope approx. 40-45%, middle slope, convex. Alpine Tundra zone.

access_notes: The 8.4 km access trail climbs 653 m vertical gain to a maximum elevation of 2830 m. You will be glad to get your legs stretched out after the long 29 km drive up the Glacier Creek FSR. Following the Duncan FSR from Argenta to the well signed right turn onto Glacier FSR is where the bone rattling begins, but once you become surrounded by the massive glaciated peaks, all discomfort disappears. Once at the parking lot, the trail switchbacks up steeply through ESSF forest, where at about 6 km you emerge into the larch studded, namesake meadows.  The tree can be seen above, to the left after you cross a bridge over a small creek. Following up through the gully you will see two large, ancient sentinels on the rocky ground above, the tree to the right #1327, and the larger more scraggy tree is # 977 "Grand Daddy Subby". There appear to be quite a few of these very old sub-alpine larches dotting the exposed ground in the meadow, so further big tree exploration of this beautiful sub-alpine area is warranted.

tree_site_notes: ESSFdk, montane.

access_notes: On the East side of Ladyslipper Trail, half way between Ladyslipper Lake and Pyramid Lake in Cathedral Provincial Park.
tree_site_notes: Healthy. A very large branch comes off the trunk 4 meters above the ground.

access_notes: On the East side of Ladyslipper Trail, half way between Ladyslipper Lake and Pyramid Lake in Cathedral Provincial Park.
tree_site_notes: Healthy with broken top.

access_notes: 75 km SE of Vanderhoof.
tree_site_notes: Healthy.

access_notes: Request access permission from the Ucluelet First Nation.  Park at the Florencia Beach parking lot and then walk through the forest to the tree.
tree_site_notes: Healthy hemlock in a grove of similar specimens, surrounded by dense salal. Intact crown.

access_notes: From the Lynn Headwaters Regional Provincial Park parking lot, take the Lynn Headwaters Trail toward Norvan Falls (7 km). Just before the falls, turn right onto the Coliseum Mountain trail. This trail is rugged and fairly vertical. Follow the yellow blazons and orange trail-marking tape. After about an hour, the trail levels out and is in more dense brush and old-growth. Follow the trail, crossing creek beds, until you reach a stony avalanche chute. You'll see Norvan Ponds (pools and waterfall) about 40 m to your left, down the chute. Keep walking on the path, which meanders up the stony avalanche chute. Look for the pink trail-marking tape in the bush to your right and walk about 15 m off the trail to the tree. The tree is above (to the right of) the path, below The Needles. The tree is not visible from the path.
tree_site_notes: Healthy, has 6 reiterations (new leaders) and broken top at 115 feet, 5 leaders forming ‘candelabra’ top.  Tree is at bottom of large avalanche chute.

access_notes: Park at the Florencia Beach parking lot and then walk through the forest to the tree.
tree_site_notes: Healthy hemlock with an intact crown surrounded by salal and other healthy specimens.

access_notes: Request access permission from the Ucluelet First Nation.  Park at the Florencia Beach parking lot and then walk through the forest to the tree.
tree_site_notes: Tree is in decline having lost 20m in ht and 8m in crown spread since it was nominated in 1986.

access_notes: From saddle between Grouse Mountain and Mount Fromme, follow hiking trail north around back of Grouse Mountain into Barrier Creek Valley. From a point approximately 100 m east of Barrier Creek, descend steep, forested slopes approximately 100 m to tree.
tree_site_notes: This was once a huge tree but now has a broken top and is barely alive.  Aspect north, slope approximately 85%, middle slope, straight, avalanche deposition area. CWHvm2.

access_notes: Follow Tahsish River to just downstream from Tahsish River/Kwois Creek confluence. (Site found in Tahsish-Kwois Provincial Park on Vancouver Island)
tree_site_notes: Level alluvial site. CWHvh1.

access_notes: Highway 28 - Campbell River to Gold River
tree_site_notes: Approximately 5 km from the trailhead some larger trees begin to show up on the scene.

access_notes: Highway 4
tree_site_notes: Situated near not too well worn, short loop trail that is intentionally leading to the Canoe Creek Cedar beside the Kennedy River.

access_notes: Montizambert Creek located in Cypress Provincial Park.

Turn off Hwy #101 heading North on the Sechelt-Roberts FSR 7472.02. Drive to intersection with Dakota Creek FSR 7575 Br.01.  Drive to proposed BCTS TFL A79517-DK42.  Follow road center line uphill into DK44. Tree is within falling boundary.
tree_site_notes: The tree has a broken top that may have been subject to a recent lightning strike.

access_notes: Turn off Hwy #101 heading North on the Sechelt-Roberts FSR 7472.02. Drive to intersection with Dakota Creek FSR 7575 Br.01.  Drive to proposed BCTS TFL A79517-DK42.  Follow road center line uphill into DK44. Tree is near proposed logging road.
tree_site_notes: The tree is healthy, growing on a 30-40% slope in a stand of other large mountain hemlocks.

access_notes: Turn off Hwy #101 heading North on the Sechelt-Roberts FSR 7472.02. Drive to intersection with Dakota Creek FSR 7575 Br.01.  Drive to proposed BCTS TFL A79517-DK42.  Follow road center line uphill into DK44.
tree_site_notes: The tree is growing in a stand with other mountain hemlocks on top of a ridge on a North facing slope.

access_notes: The small settlement of Ferguson is accessed from Highway 31 near Trout Lake. The gravel road climbs up beside the Lardeau River where you will come to a wye, turn right onto the Alpha FSR and drive about 500 m, where on the right a myriad of trails lead down towards the river. The big hemlock is hiding down in the wetness with a bunch of spruce and cedars.
tree_site_notes: There are quite a few big hemlocks lurking in this forest. This particular tree was the largest found and over 400 years old.

access_notes: The Below the Gods Trail is accessed in the Smallwood Creek area. Turn off of Highway 3a onto Beasley Road, then make the first quick right onto Queen Victoria St. This road transitions into the Smallwood FSR. There are too many junctions to describe, so utilize Trailforks to find this trail.
tree_site_notes: Having been given a tip about the big trees along this trail, the mixture of cedar and hemlock is a common site in this region. The presence of sub-surface water where this big hemlock is growing, has obviously had a positive influence on its growth. This is a Skookum tree.

access_notes: Davis Creek Trail is accessed from Highway 31 to the north of Kaslo, near the village of Lardeau. The Provincial Park campground is a good place to park your vehicle, and then begin the steep climb up to the Rim. The forest changes to Larch, then into a cedar/hemlock as the ground flattens out a bit. Water does not seem to know where to run, and the ground is wet everywhere. The trail ends at Fishhook Lake, with big trees to be found all around.
tree_site_notes: This mighty hemlock was very close to the trail, with a lot of the trees having been given appreciative names. This guy is “Hemi”

access_notes: Travel Akokalyx FSR to 12.5 km then turn south on Crawford FSR. 4 km on south side of road at small pullout. walk in 50m. Cutblock boundary nearby.
tree_site_notes: Slanted 15%, broken top, Twisted branches looks like mistletoe. In lush bench area above near Akokalyx river N side. Many moderately large cedar approx between 1 and 1.75 m. Low growing devils club.  Very open and park like.

access_notes: From Highway 3 when travelling west from Creston, and right before the yellow avalanche closure gate is a large pull-out parking area on your left, where some unobtrusive trail signs are attached to the trees. Situated quite high up on the trees so as to not disappear as the snow pack gets deeper. A trail heads down to where it crosses Summit Creek, and then a loop configuration allows you to chose your direction on the 1.3 km route. I like to walk it both ways, as new delights are revealed every time.
tree_site_notes: Western hemlocks of this enormity are not that common, generally succumbing to old age, rot, blowdown, or casual chainsaw death. The sheltered high elevation environment seems well suited for this big tree. This is the biggest tree found in this grove, but there are likely some larger ones to be found if getting off trail is your thing.

access_notes:
From Crescent Spur, drive south on Loos Road towards Highway 16. Turn left on Highway 16 and drive southeast for 8.9 km towards the Goat River bridge. Just before the highway bridge over the Goat River, park on the left (north) side of the highway at the Goat River Rest Area. From the rest area, follow instructions for "Goat River Canyon Trail" on Trailpeak.                  the Goat River Rest Area. From the rest area, follow instructions for "Goat River Canyon Trail" on Trailpeak. 

The trail is accessed by an old road on the south side of Highway 16, 1/2km before the Goat River bridge and rest area. The old road is easily missed by those driving on Highway 16, because of the steep drop it takes off the highway. If you do not have a 4-WD vehicle, it is best to park at the Goat River rest area and walk west on the south side of Highway 16 to spot the rough access road. If you drive down the old road, there is a small clearing a short ways down with room to park.The hike initially follows the old road. You will cross a rough wooden bridge over a creek. Shortly afterwards, you will reach a fork in the road where the right side is very overgrown. Take the left fork. A short distance after this, there is a second fork in the road, where an ATV trail continues to the right and the left side appears less worn-in. At this second fork, follow the left (less worn-in) side. After a minute or so, take the trail on the left leading away from the old road and into the forest (it should be flagged). From here, the trail is easy to follow. You will stay on the plateau before crossing a stream and descending towards the canyon. After the stream is where the very old trees are located.GPS Coordinates:- Old road off Highway 16: 53.4924063, -120.6176087- Goat River Canyon (trail end point, for reference, to ensure one is hiking in the correct direction): 53.4772961, -120.6406700.
tree_site_notes: Found in a hemlock forest in the ICH BEC zone with little understory vegetation.

access_notes: Midway between Bridesville and Rock Creek on the connector.   South of Johnstone Creek PP, 1 km north of US border.
tree_site_notes: Ancient, lightning blackened top, large bole to about 100'.

access_notes: To locate this site on the Lizard Range, drive right on through the campsite on Mount Fernie Park Road, until you reach a trailhead kiosk on the left, where an obvious aluminum bridge crosses Lizard Creek. Immediately after exiting from the bridge turn left onto the signed “Gorby Trail”. This is actually an old road that leads up into the lower basin of Cedar Bowl. Upon arrival in the big basin, take the road to right, Red Tree Road, and follow it for about 500 m. where the Snakebite Trail ushers you into the forest on your right.
tree_site_notes:
Many fire survived veteran Western Larch spire up from the Western Red Cedar forest on the lower slopes of the Lizard Range. The difficulty field locating them, in the absence of a trail, is the thick alder, buckbrush, and devil's club choked underbrush that presents the challenge. The larch tree sampled was right beside the Snakebite Mountain Bike Trail, so can be located a bit more easily.
This stand of trees appears very healthy, likely, with todays fire suppression prioratization in proximity to an urban area, could live another 500 years? Age estimate from annular ring count of a "cookie" of a similar diameter tree in close proximity is 425 years.

access_notes: Wally’s Follies is an obscure ski run at Fernie Alpine Resort. It is most easily accessed in the winter when skiing. If interested in visiting this site in summer, the easiest approach would be to walk up Gorby Trail from the Mt Fernie Provincial Park to where it meets Red Tree Road. Follow the road to the right until you come to the Snakebite Trail (also many big larches) sign on the right, but turn left and head up into the bush where an assortment of very large larch and cedar trees are gathered.
tree_site_notes: A western larch tree of this height stands out above the surrounding forest canopy. I was looking for a big cedar, which I found, but was pleasantly surprised to come across this old larch, with its battle scarred base and stout trunk, it was a very nice sight.
Very healthy with small dead top.

access_notes:
From Kimberley : Take Hwy 95A towards Cranbrook. Turn R onto St Mary's Lake Rd. Turn L onto Lakeside Rd and continue onto Hellroaring FSR. Keep R at first fork, then stay L on Hellroaring FSR (do NOT go onto Meachen FSR). You will cross Hellroaring Creek over a bridge.TThe tree is 50m back from the 9km marker and roughly 4km past the 31km marker. The boulderfield will be on your L, the last km marker I remember seeing was for 30km up. If you cross a 2nd bridge, you have gone too far (but there is a good turnaround spot there). The biggest larch is within 20m of the road. The others can be located by scrambling around the boulderfield. 
From Cranbrook: Take Hwy 95A towards Kimberley. Continue through Marysville. Turn L onto St Mary's Lake Rd; the rest is the same as above.
tree_site_notes: Minimal lower stem damage/decay, but displays signs of larger branch and top breakage characteristic of larger larches. The largest larch was located at the toe of a scree slope, NW aspect.  Growing all around the edges scree slope were similarly large larches: 26 trees measured were >3m and 4 were >4m. Many of the trees, especially those on the southeast (top of the slope) side of the scree slope bore fire scars and charring suggestive that they survived a fire decades ago.  Height to live crown 8m, ht to broken top 39m, branches ascend upward a few meters. Woodpecker holes on bottom 2 m.

access_notes: From Jaffray or Elko drive down to Kikomun Creek Prov. Park.  Take Teepee Cr Rd. west across Koocanusa Lake, past the campground/boat access. Then head south on Caven Cr FSR (starting at 15.5 km).  At 32.5 km turn left onto Bloom FSR, at 42.5 turn right onto Middle Bloom and park just past the 45 km sign.  It is a short hike down to the creek through ~50 yr old Lodgepole pine second growth.
tree_site_notes:
This tree has some scorch at the bottom, but is otherwise quite intact.  Remnants of a whorl of large branches is evident at about 6m up.  Two other larch trees are within 5-6m of this one, forming quite a trio!  The two largest of the three are within 5m of a tributary to Bloom Creek.  The other large larch (128cm DBH) is leaning downstream and would be close to 55m if growing straight up. The smaller (~1m) larch has a broken top, totald height is about 35m.  Another large larch lies toppled over the creek, making a natural bridge just upstream.
A proposed bridge location and road centre line is marked out about 20m upstream and upslope from the two closer trees of the trio.  
The surrounding riparian area contains a range of species - spruce, balsam, cedar, hemlock and Douglas fir but all the largest trees are western larch up and down the creek for about 100m, with large live trees, short and tall snags, and down trees. Most of these larch are in the 80cm diam range.

access_notes: The Big Larch Trail is accessed from a roadside pull-out that is on the right a few km north of Hills on Highway 6. A signed trailhead directs you up a de-commissioned logging road. At the 3rd switchback an old skid trail heads off to the south, where you will cross a small creek. The big larches are just above on the edge of a fairly recently logged area.
tree_site_notes: Wow!, what a tree. A friend of mine from Rosebery sent me a photo of himself under a big larch. He said it was over 5 ‘ in diameter. While not quite making that size, this is an outstanding trees as the photos reveal.
Healthy, dead top, seed tree in old clearcut.

access_notes: Drive up Gerry Sorensen Way, past Kimberley Alpine Resort and continue until the road becomes North Star Drive. The Nordic Club is at the end of North Star Drive.  Take any of the fun trails around to the south end of the Centennial loop to Iker's landing.  Then take Landsem south.  About half way along Landsem look for a smaller trail marked Moe's Canyon/Magic Line.  Follow this steep up to the top.  You are now looking north at the old growth larch patch.  Magic line cuts right, to the east of the patch and Moe's Canyon Trail goes north through the patch past the Mussers Plateau Trail junction and continues north into Moe's Canyon.  Moe's #1 is just east of the trail, about 60m north of the Magic line junction.  This and the other tallest trees in Moes are also visible from the south end of Larch Loop Trail.
tree_site_notes: This tree is in a one ha patch of old growth of western larch/Douglas-fir/spruce growing in a flat area right at the south end of Moe's Canyon.  Logging occured in 2006 to the south and east of this patch and elsewhere within the Kimberley Nordic Trails area.  The patch contains at least 13 large trees over 100 cm DBH and eight of these trees are over 50m in height.  All the largest trees are western larch but there are two Douglas-fir trees scoring over 300 points.  This is the highest ranking tree found based on height, circumference and crown size.   The smaller mature western larch trees at the periphery of this area are well over 400 years old so this tree could be in the 600 - 800 yr range.

access_notes: Gilnockie Provincial Park and Ecological Reserve are a long ways from anywhere. Located close to the US border between Grasmere and Yahk, this 100 km section of wilderness (minus all the logging blocks) is accessed from Caven Creek FSR, Bloom Creek FSR, and Ward Creek FSR. Gilnockie Creek is best accessed by driving 2.3 km west of the Yahk River bridge, and then bushwhacking down to the creek along the edge of a clearcut. Many superb larch specimens reside along the creek.
tree_site_notes: Not often a grouping of veteran western larches is encountered. This assembly of massive trees residing on a bench above Gilnockie Creek supports quite a display of greatness. The larch is an amazing 517 years old.

access_notes: Drive up Gerry Sorensen Way, past Kimberley Alpine Resort and continue until the road becomes North Star Drive. The Nordic Club is at the end of North Star Drive.  Take any of the fun trails around to the south end of the Centennial loop to Iker's landing.  Then take Landsem south.  About half way along Landsem look for a smaller trail marked Moe's Canyon/Magic Line.  Follow this steep up to the top.  You are now looking north at the old growth larch patch.  Magic line cuts right, to the east of the patch and Moe's Canyon Trail goes north through the patch past the Mussers Plateau Trail junction and continues north into Moe's Canyon.  Moe's #1 is just east of the trail, about 60m north of the Magic line junction.  Moe's #3 is 35m further, 15m east of the trail. This and the other tallest trees in Moes are also visible from the south end of Larch Loop Trail.
tree_site_notes: This tree has a small burn scar at the base, a large burl at 18m, broken top at 39m and a Y-shaped live top.  This would be the highest ranking tree in this area if not for the broken top. It does have the largest circumference and crown size, and the most majestic look overall.

access_notes: Giveout Creek FSR is located above and to the south of Nelson where a right turn just past the Waldorf School turn-off leads up and up for about 8 km. The Bear’s Den trail is best referenced on Trailforks to locate where to head up.
tree_site_notes: In awe about the big cedars and hemlocks that have man-made biking structures winding up and over some wild terrain, these big larches could go by un-noticed. The tree is over 400 years old, and it appears that it will be around for a long time yet.

access_notes: Horse Barn Valley Interpretive Forest. Driving Directions:   High-ground-clearance vehicle is recommended. From the Kimberley Riverside Campground and RV Resort it is 8.9 kilometres to the parking area. From the campground, drive west on the paved St. Mary Lake Road for 4.1 km. Turn right on the Matthew Creek Forestry Road and just before the 2km sign turn right again on a narrower, rougher gravel road marked with a HBV signpost. After about 1.5km veer left then right to keep climbing to the parking area and kiosks.   The Western Larch tree is a short walk from the kiosk in on Talus Trail. Cross a small bridge, then a board walk and 50m along the larch is on your left, at a small Queen's Cup interpretive sign.
tree_site_notes: The tree is located in the Horse Barn Valley Interpretive Forest which is managed by the Kimberley Nature Park Society. This tree has scorched bark and a scar running 8m up the top side of the tree.  It has a large fork at 16m and a broken top/fork at 40m. It is growing on a steep sidehill and is leaning almost over the trail. This tree is just North of a nice patch of old growth cedar.

access_notes: Drive up Gerry Sorensen Way, past Kimberley Alpine Resort and continue until the road becomes North Star Drive. The Nordic Club is at the end of North Star Drive.  Take any of the fun trails around to the south end of the Centennial loop to Iker's landing.  Then take Landsem south.  About half way along Landsem look for a smaller trail marked Moe's Canyon/Magic Line.  Follow this steep up to the top of hill.  You are now looking north at the old growth larch patch.  Magic line cuts right, to the east of the patch.  Moe's Canyon Trail goes north past the largest trees and continues past the Mussers Plateau Trail junction and north into Moe's Canyon.  Moe's #2 is 20m west of the trail, about 50m NNW of the Magic line junction.  From this junction look for a tall dead top, it belongs to a mostly dead western larch, about 20m west of our tree.  This and the other tallest trees in Moes are also visible from the south end of Larch Loop Trail.  Moes #1, Moes #2 and the dead top larch are also visible from around the first switchback on Musser's trail.
tree_site_notes: This tree is in a one ha patch of old growth western larch/douglas fir/spruce growing in a flat area right at the south end of Moe's Canyon.  Logging occured in 2006 to the south and east of this patch and elsewhere within the Kimberley Nordic Trails area.  This tree is easily missed since it is west of the trail by 20m, just north of the more open logged area.  This tree has a deep, 2m fire scar at the base but otherwise seems to be in great condition.

tree_site_notes: Tree is healthy and carries a large crown. The lower trunk is festooned with burls and hemlock seedlings, and above, a massive fluted trunk supports a large head of reiterated trunks, many of which are dead, a characteristic of old red cedars.

access_notes:
From the small town of Youbou, on the Eastern end of Lake Cowichan, head Westward on the North Shore Road,
continuing all the way past the lake on Cowichan Main and eventually following the Nitinat River.
Turn right at T-Intersection ( 48.8627379, -124.6438995 ) over the bridge which crosses Nitinat River, following
Carmanah Main. A visit to the waterfalls on the Little Nitinat Falls is recommended for a quick break (unmarked pull
off near 48.871476, -124.687404 ).
Follow Carmanah Main until a bridge on your left crosses the Little Nitinat River onto Flora Main ( 48.8994754,
-124.6887141 ).
Follow Flora until you reach Upper Klanawa Main ( 48.861963, -124.739748 ) and turn left.
Not long after passing Newstead Main (do not take this road), the road starts climbing and splits.
Take the left spur K-265, up a steep pitch and around a tight bend ( 48.8267934, -124.7812745 ).
After some time, along the South side of K-265 there are a couple of small lakes accessed via a short spur (approx
48.8274633, -1248130282 ), this is where you can access the Fairy Bell Cedar at Dorothy Lake (at the head of the
more westward lake, 48.825688, -124.822826 ).
Please be advised that this is an ACTIVE logging area, follow suitably safe driving techniques and be vigilant and
courteous to other road users. It is advised to only visit this area on weekends when logging activities are minimal.
This is a remote area without cellular reception so plan your trip accordingly. Input your coordinates before you leave
home. In general the gravel road driving is reasonable for most vehicles, but fill your tank and definitely bring a full
sized spare tire along for this trip.
tree_site_notes:
- The Fairy Bell Cedar appears healthy, shows typical conical form and has two main leaders which are bare
at the tip and a smaller third leader.
-The Tree is located on a flat drainage area which flows to the head of nearby Dorothy Lake, at the edge of
a recent Cutblock between this and another small lake. These lakes drain into the Klanawa River,
1 km to the west. A fine old Sitka spruce tree stands about 50m to the South West of Fairy Bell.
-Although currently this area has been and is still being aggressively logged, numerous fine and large
specimens of Sitka spruce, Western Red cedar and even occasional Douglas fir still stand in the Klanawa
River Valley System. For more detailed information about the trees of this region visit the Vancouver Island
Prominent Tree Survey, a project hosted by the coastaltrailcollective.com

tree_site_notes:
This cedar is absolutely enormous. It's huge, riveted trunk looks like the chest of a humpback whale. A number of large limbs then burst skyward, creating healthy and bushy crown. Unfortunately, however, like Big Lonely Doug, it stands alone in a clearcut from 2019. It's likely that its health will suffer now that the forest is gone around it. After surviving for many, many centuries, only time will tell if it will make it to the end of the next one.

*There is a notable spiral cedar within viewing distance of this one and another impressive lone cedar a bit further up the road as well.

From here you need to bushwhack down to the tree. There are many other giants to be seen here too!
tree_site_notes: This tree is magnificent and very burly. It grows on the edge of a creek bank in a fairly flat and open section of Eden Grove. There are many other giant trees in the vicinity as well. This area is currently unprotected and has falling boundary and road location tape throughout the grove.

access_notes: Turning west off of Highway 19, directly across from the Sayward exit, you will find yourself on the Salmon River Main. Accessing the park is not that straight forward, as there is no signage, and the White River FSR is somewhat off direction from the paved Salmon River Main, which lured me off course for about 6 km before realizing that the river was on the wrong road I was supposed to be on. Backtracking, I found where I missed the turn-off at the junction. The rough gravel road rises steeply from the Salmon River valley, where at the 17 km marker a junction where the road goes down to a bridge crossing the White River, is not the right direction, stay left on the Victoria Main for a further 6 km, where the Park Boundary sign is your first indication that you are getting close to your destination. A short distance further, and an obscure (facing in the wrong direction of travel) sign directs you towards a short trail that leads you through the big Douglas-fir trees towards the river.
tree_site_notes: Touted as the "Cathedral Grove of the North“.  The tree is within the protected area of the White River Provincial Park, which is a narrow linear strip of preserved old-growth, with extensive harvesting visual all around it. The Douglas-fir, tree #1292, is right beside this short trail, before you get to the river. The western redcedar, tree #1293, is upstream, off trail, through some flat, but deadfall barriered ground.  The Sitka spruce, tree #1294, is very close to the western redcedar.

This area was previously potected as an Old-Growth Management Area but was later privatized for the Ditidaht First Nation as part of the their ITA and who have now logged much of the old-growth along the lake. The area is home to some of the very biggest ancient cedars and amazing CMTs - where they still remain.

tree_site_notes: This huge cedar grows right on the edge of a flat bench overlooking another bench below. A truly impressive spot to just stop and take it all in. A second giant cedar grows just a short distance away downslope. This area is unprotected and may be logged at any time.

access_notes: Starting from Lake Cowichan take South Shore Main to Caycuse Main until you can drop down onto Haddon Main. Follow that to the end of the road where you see a new cutblock where my before & after photos were taken. Drive through the cutblock until you can access a spur road that takes you down across a creek and up the adjacent hillside. Halfway up this road park. The tree is up hill on the left above the road cut. Use GPS for final way-finding.
tree_site_notes: This tree is an absolute giant. It has a massive, burly base and a super thick trunk that towers skyward to a multi-forked top. It appears to be within a retention patch but only 50ft away from the falling boundary tape of a planned cutblock nearby. Other giants exists in the forest around it as well. A true wonder to behold.

A big, beautiful cedar with lovely coloured bark that swirls around. The tree has a hole that you can crawl right through at the base!
A giant cedar with whiteish bark. Looks like it's been around for awhile. Will probably be around for a long time still!
A cedar covered in small burls. Looks like a witches nose!
A massive cedar with a bear den.
A solid cedar growing in a lush patch of ferns.

Monumental redcedar with an active bear den. A really special tree and spot.
An towering cedar that soars skyward. Standing here feels like you're in the redwoods of California. This might be where all the fairys live.
A twisted redcedar that looks like a piece of red licorice!

A super giant cedar that makes you stop and say 'WOW'! This one really stands out and with the other big trees around it, makes for an amazing experience. A full sized Hemlock is also growing out of the trunk.
A super hefty cedar growing in a small creek ravine. A wall of wood!

A giant solid cedar that is now within an approved cutblock.

access_notes: Take FSR's from Powell River to point closest to GPS and hike in through the second-growth.
tree_site_notes: The largest cedar in a stunning pocket of old-growth at the base of a towering cliff in the Eldred River Valley.
A giant redcedar tree with some big burls on the trunk. May now be in a retention patch.
A massive redcedar with a warbly trunk that has the appearance of an old wax candle. Very cool and impressive tree
A stately cedar in an area with a number of other large trees. Another larger cedar is found further on but had died.
A monumental old-growth redcedar in the forest off the edge of a cutblock from 2017. Has a nice bear den on the side. A prime example of the amazing cedars this region would have once produced.
A beautiful cedar with a big burl growing on its side that resides at the base of a gentle slope covered with deer fern and trilliums. A place to visit in spring time and admire!

A wall of a cedar with a bear den at its base. Behind it is a giant nurse log that must have been an old friend. Beyond that, second-growth plantations begins, a stark contrast to the strip of old-growth left here.

A twisting and whirling cedar of epic proportions. Its trunk and root base spirals upwards as if someone grabbed it from the top and wrung it out. It's a work of art and a wonder to behold. This grove of trees here, small as it is, contains some of the finest examples of redcedars.
From a distance I thought this was one tree, and the biggest ever at that. Turns out its clearly two trees once you view it from the side. Still an incredible sight to see nonetheless!
A phenominal cedar tree growing in an unprotected old-growth grove. Lots of cool shapes and twists to it. Some culturally modified trees can be found on the opposite side of the road from this tree.
A big and scraggly cedar along the west side of Cheewhat Lake.
A beefy cedar growing on a slight ridgeline. It's a huff to get to this tough lookin' tree.

Like Pokemon, 'you gotta catch em' all', and Burl'batron is a might fine specimin at that. Huge contorted burls adorn the face of this ancient cedar, a sight that only a mother, or big tree hunter, could love.
This one's a big guy!
A big old cedar growing next to a multi-spired cedar that looks like Medusa! A fun place to find yourself in along the lakeshore.

A massive redcedar with unique burls and branches standing in an open, almost park-like area. Not too hard to get too from the lakeshore once you've paddled over. The tree was originally pictured in some of Maywell's old film photos from around Cheewhat Lake. If you visit one tree on this side of the lake, make it this one!
This redcedar is covered with plants, has multiple spires, and a little hobbit hole in the bottom. Mother Earth approves!
A wall of wood that eventually splits into two. Stands out in this zone!
A creek flows right through the base of this cedar, which also happens to be a great place to take a nap.
A giant hollow cedar that you can stand inside growing just up the hill from a small creek.
A dry den in this ancient, castle-like cedar provides a great shelter for hobbits trying to avoid the dangers lurking in these regions. You may be sharing it with a black bear though.
A wavy and warbled cedar growing atop a remote slope amongst some other nice cedar specimins. Unprotected
A castle-like Cedar with striking spires shooting skyward. This giant grows on the edge of an old cutblock in a patch of unprotected old-growth. Another giant cedar can be found closer to the road.
A big old cedar with some heft to it. Marked as a leave tree in an unprotected forest at risk of being future logging.
A beautiful cedar currently wrapped in orange bands in preperation for falling within a recommended deferral area. The tree is just one of many giants in an extensive grove that should be protected.

Irregular circumference due to 8 stems, 2 stems visibly hollow but trees otherwise healthy with lush crown and alive tops.  On moderate, rocky, NW slope, 35 m below logging road. Devil's club, hemlock, fern, western yew, deciduous. Near small rockslide area. Less than 5 m from creek.

tree_site_notes: The Radius Tree has been heavily trafficked, and now has a protective fence around it to protect its roots. The buttressed base of this tree is amazing.

access_notes: From Golden BC drive west 45 km on TransCanada Highway 1, as you start to climb up from the Columbia River bridge crossing, keep an eye to the right for a sign that says Kinbasket Lake Resort, turn off of the highway here. The rough gravel road (Columbia West FSR) descends steeply down to where the now closed Resort is situated at the Beaver River bridge crossing. Set your odometer to “0” here. Drive 58.7 km to where the Smith Creek drainage crosses the road. At this switchback, the very overgrown spur follows the drainage to where the road is obstructed by a small landslide. We had to back down from here, so best to just park at the junction and walk up to the tree. It is only about 850 m until this massive tree shows up on the left side of the road. You can’t miss it!
tree_site_notes: The tree is somewhat solitary, and appears to have been graciously left behind. With huge limbs spreading out above as cedars. We circumnavigated around its girth, where the Interior sized D-Tape couldn’t wrap the entire circumference. Our explorations down below towards the creek turned up some considerable sized western red cedars, western hemlocks, and a notable Engelmann spruce. This region is worthy of further explorations, where myth’s of even larger cedars are whispered by the locals.

tree_site_notes: This tree is located a little way off of the boardwalk. Its stout columnar trunk stood out in the jungle of devil’s club, and lured me humbly over to take its measurements.

access_notes: The Kokanee Creek Old Growth Trail is found by following the Kokanee Glacier access road off of Highway #3A for 12 km. on a 2 wd suitable gravel road that climbs steeply up the drainage. B.C. Recreation Sites and Trails has a well positioned sign on the highway directing you to this preserve. The trailhead is well signed, and a few pullouts are available for parking.
tree_site_notes: The Old Growth forest occupying the flanks of Kokanee Creek appears to be thriving in this wet belt environment. Only threat is perhaps over visitation. Evidence of past logging and mining activity have fortunately not compromised this otherwise sensitive site.

access_notes: The Staubert Lake Cedars are tucked away beside the Trout Lake highway, and are easily accessed. A stylish wood  carved sign alerts you to the trailhead, where a small pull-out beside the road provides parking for a few vehicles.
tree_site_notes: This is the first tree encountered as you enter this enchanting grove. Spread out on the Beaton River /Poulman Creek floodplain, there are many spectacular trees, however the entry sentinel, with its own viewing chair is outstanding.

access_notes: Boat access only traveling west across Revelstoke Lake. Good launch point at Carnes Creek Recreation Site accessed via Hwy 23 north of Revelstoke. Tree is located approximately 2 to 2.5 km up a flagging marked trail . Trail is accessed from a small flagged drainage approx 500 m north of the mouth of Frisby Creek. Accessing area through Frisby Creek not recommended.
tree_site_notes:
Tree has significant graduated multidirectional lean. Tree is on edge of landslide area and has some mechanical damage and is surrounded by avalanche debris. This area is prone to avalanche due to steep slopes above.

The tree is located in a spectacular contiguous old growth area in the Frisby Creek drainage that has not been significantly impacted by logging. There has been some shake bolting and selective logging lower in the valley. The valley is towered over by steep slopes and the tree is on a bench situated above a lower bench along Frisby Creek and below steep slopes leading into the alpine. Moist and lush area. Lots of Devil's club and moss, abundant mushrooms. Lots of moose activity and bear dens in the area.

access_notes: The turn off to the Cedar Grove Trail is 10 km from Highway 23.  A well signed forestry road to the left is followed for 5.5 km to the trailhead. The gravel road is quite rough and rocky, but is navigable with a 2 wheel drive vehicle. On the way up, there is a wye that is un-signed, so attention should be paid here to get where you want to go. The right branch is your direction.
tree_site_notes: This triple trunked cedar is a very solid looking tree. With black gooseberry trailing around at its base, it seemed well accompanied to put on a few more years growth.

access_notes: Following Mt. Fernie Park Rd. from Highway 3 to Island Lakes 2nd parking lot is where the trailhead to the Od Growth Trail begins.
tree_site_notes: Venturing off of the trail to a floodplain bench above Lizard Creek this massive tree stands in a meadow environment of Cow Parsnip and Devil’s club

tree_site_notes: Tree has partial defoliated castled top and is at slight angle approx 5-10%.

If the Lodge is open for summer guests the gate will be open. Otherwise you can walk / ski or ride your bike up the road or provided trails.
About 4 km up the road a second trailhead parking area for the Old Growth trail is on the right. You can park here, and walk up the road about another 50 m and an old spur to the right (the winter road) leads up another 50 m where the "Mammoth" is hiding in the bushes on the left.
tree_site_notes: Included in the trees height is a 4.0 m. dead spire top. The tree is surrounded with heavy underbrush, making accessibility somewhat difficult. The bulbous base of the tree is typical of the many old cedars growing in this area.

access_notes: The Eagle River Nature Park is located on the opposite side of Highway 1 from  the Yard Creek Provincial Park campground in Malakwa (12 km east of Sicamous). This is a section of divided highway, so turning onto the Malakwa north frontage road is a bit challenging. Once on the north frontage road head to the west end where the trailhead parking lot is located. The 6 km loop trail has a few cedar groves, with the Grandmother of the Eagle tree being at the furthest out on the loop trail.
tree_site_notes: Tree is luxuriating in the riparian area of the Eagle River, and enjoys lots of space allowing for the impressive spread of the branches. The flat, floodplain, and watersoaked surroundings provide ideal growing conditions for these big cedar trees.

access_notes: To access the tree: 1) Drive from Prince George to the Hungary Creek FSR, approximately 80km east along Highway 16, 2) Drive approximately 2.8km along the Hungary Creek FSR, following resource road radio protocols.  Park at an appropriate location, 3) Tree is located approximately 100m south of the Hungary Creek FSR.
tree_site_notes: Tree condition and health: dead top, tree appears healthy. Ht to live crown is 31.1, ht to dead top is 34.0. Site conditions: located on 5% slope with NW aspect, mid-slope position. There was a fire in this stand ~100 years ago.  Many larger cedar in the stand were burned.

access_notes: Drive north up the Duncan FSR to the top of the lake. Cross Duncan River bridge, and look for road to left. Gate is sometimes closed, but walking in a couple of km will land you in this great forest collection on both sides of the road. The further you go, the bigger the trees get.
tree_site_notes: Sampled tree was on the west side of the road, standing amongst some grizzly bear chewed skunk baggage, and thick alder.

access_notes: Easily accessible, this tree can be found by driving on West Creston Road, just off Highway 3. At approximately 4.7 km you will come to a bridge that crosses Corn Creek. A small pullout just before the bridge, is the parking spot.
tree_site_notes: Standing alone beside Corn Creek this tree is very visible, and the area around the tree has been heavily visited. A view from the other side of the creek is worthwhile.

access_notes: The Island Lake lodge access road winds up through spectacular old-growth. Just find a place to park and explore.

access_notes: From Revelstoke take Highway 1 West.  At the junction 500m from west end of Revelstoke, turn north. Travel 6.5 km to Frisby FSR. Follow Frisby FSR North for 20k and take the west spur.  Go up the spur for 3.2 km. Walk 100m downhill off of the road, cross the small creek to where the tree stands.
tree_site_notes: The tree has a fairly uniform trunk with slight twist all the way to the top, is leaning approximately 4 degrees and has a turreted top.  The canopy is healthy with some low branches and heavy lichen load.  There is an animal nest partway up the tree, with a big hollow and marks at the opening, possibly a porcupine.  The tree is next to small creek, surrounded by medium density devils club. It is located in an old growth grove containing numerous big western redcedars and hemlocks. The tree is in a flat section of grove near the creek, just down from the logging road. The forest is highly productive forest with evidence of ungulate and bear activity.

The tree is very compact and straight with basically no buttresses. The tree has multiple tops and branches stick out notably. In an area with 7 cedars of significance including a close tree with 8.0m of diameter. This tree is in a cut block and is scheduled to be harvested.

tree_site_notes: The Cedar Sister is located in the 3rd grove along the trail, and is a beautiful tree. Nestled in amongst some other sisters, her bark shines, and her long limbs seep down for embraces.

There are also two sets of 3 twin cedars that are gorgeous. The tree is on a slope of about 20 degrees and NW aspect. There is a low gnarled branch about 7m up the tree. The tree has light lichen load moderate flagging and the under story consists of vine maple, pacific yew and devils club. This tree is on the edge of a cut block, but is not in the block.
