access_notes: From Revelstoke drive 108 kn north on Hwy 23. Turn east on Goldstream FSR. Between km 20-21 look for small south spur. . Walk south up 450 m. Tree is 100 m upslope travelling SE.
tree_site_notes: Trees has a forked stem approx 1/3 way up. The area is a lush, north facing, moderately inclined lower slope although where the tree is is relatively flat. There is lots of Devils club and larger shrubs. The grove and slope on which this tree is situated has many other trees (rough estimate of 10-15) in the 7-7.5 m circumference range. This grove is in a cutblock slated for imminent logging and is one of the few unlogged areas on the lower slopes of the Goldstream FSR.

access_notes: Minor amount of blowdown, regen close to Hwy but forest floor and canopy open up before rocky outcrop uphill. Unknown cultural history.  Area has potential Culturally Modified Trees, and has been previously surveyed for Timber and most likely Ecotyping.  Very old flagging found throughout, near potential CMTs and large timber stands.  Multiple human-made "test" holes found throughout the forest, as well as a potentially "stripped" Cedar tree.  Area was part of a 2008 push by local organizations to introduce an investigation by the Forestry Board (Dome Creek area) as to the impact of logging in ICH stands in the Robson Valley "Funnel" and as a result an extensive Old Growth Management Area Plan was introduced.  This "island" is an "Ancient" area (as B.C.Forestmap.com age class) which was left out of OGMA areas, deemed fragmented due to previous logging operations. Area is known for Caribou.  SARA listed species found within and above (previously documented on inaturalist) the "island" such as Nephroma occultum (Cryptic paw) and potential for Smokers Lung (Lobaria retigera) due to noted sites nearby.  Beautiful highway site, tree is visible from the road.  In summertime the area will be abundant with Devils Club.  Easy to get to and a magnificent little nook and a pleasant day hike area.
tree_site_notes: From Prince George Drive East on Hwy 16 to Dome Creek Rd. East of The Ancient Forest/Chun T'oh Whudujut Provincial Park and Protected Area. *12.5 km After the Dome Creek Rd. Hwy Intersection (Joe Boo's Mobile Eatery) there is a small turnaround and garbage disposal location on the North Side of Hwy. This is a Good Parking Spot. If you pass Walker Creek FSR you have gone too far.* Tree is located on the South (SSW) side of Hwy, roughly 80-100 m from the parking area and 40-60 m from the brushed road edge. Hikers must climb up the steep ditch embankment and into the forest, minor elevation gain after entry into Mature Stand Area. System of very large Trees and Alli's Hollow are along a small plateau between the Hwy and a Rocky Ridge above, leading to a Silviculture regen area.

access_notes: The trailhead for the Lazy Lizard is located at Island Lake Lodge’s 1st parking lot. The tree is about 4 km up the trail.
tree_site_notes: There are many large cedars that stud this trail. The sampled tree is off to the side aways, and is quite obscured by its very long branches that extend right into the surrounding alder and devil’s club.

access_notes: The paved Mica Creek highway travels for 100 km north of Revelstoke. Downie Creek is one of the major drainages that connect to Revelstoke Lake (see Columbia River). The tree is located a few km up the Bigmouth Creek FSR, where it forks down to BMX bridge.
tree_site_notes: With active logging going on all around you, and recently logged blocks visible in every direction, it is amazing this grove of trees is still standing. Luckily, and perhaps because of riparian setback requirements this grove of big trees is nestled in beside Bigmouth Creek.

access_notes: The Big Bend Highway heads north from Highway 1 at Donald. The Giant Cedars Rec. Site is on the left side of the gravel road, and is well signed.
tree_site_notes: Located in the Help Creek floodplain the “Giant Cedars” line the trail through this very wet site. The sampled tree had its roots extending right into the creek.

access_notes: The Wap FSR extends from Three Valley Gap to Lumby. A spur referred to as Bottoms Rd. accesses this beautiful setting, where a plentiful grove of big cedars and hemlocks reside in a large seepage area above the lakes.
tree_site_notes: A luxuriant green surrounds you as you enter into this very boggy site, where big trees are nurtured by just the right stuff.

access_notes: Tree is located in the Duncan/Lardeau Flats Conservation Area.  Where the Duncan and Lardeau River converge at the north end of Kootenay Lake the delta flats provide an important habitat for: well everything. Access is at a signed, small gated pull-out just to the south of Meadow Creek.
tree_site_notes: The long branches of this tree hide its magnificence. Due to the open space afforded, this tree has taken full advantage of its surroundings, or lack thereof.

access_notes: Orca Road is an old skid trail that traverses at the base of the Lizard Range. A bridge crossing Lizard Creek, just upstream of the sawdust pile meadow in Cedar Valley is the trailhead.
tree_site_notes: Taking the time to grow lichen on your bark is a cooperative effort. This epiphyte and big cedar have done a good job, and the crop shows.

tree_site_notes: With a highway on one side, a logging road on the other, this grove is pinched in just above the Downie River escarpment. A very jungly approach is required to access from the highway. From the logging spur above is much easier, as I discover on my exit.

access_notes: Driving north on the Trout Lake Highway (gravel) from Meadow Creek, a small settlement of Poplar Creek is reached. At Rapid Creek, a well signed trailhead is positioned to direct you to the trail.
tree_site_notes: Standing in the expansive floodplain of the Lardeau River this huge tree is the first one to greet you when you enter the forest.

access_notes: From Revelstoke drive 108 kn north on Hwy 23. Turn east on Goldstream FSR. Between km 31 and 32 on Goldsteam FSR stop before creek crossing. Tree is located approximately 200 meters from the road walking north.
tree_site_notes: Tree is a fairly solid and uniform diameter column with only a light flair and a full canopy. It is located in a beautiful valley bottom grove along the south side of the Goldstream River. The tree was one of the largest we found valley bottom up the Goldstream FSR. The grove is located at the confluence of a smaller stream entering into the river, contains wetland areas and shows evidence of annual flooding at high water.This grove is one of the bigger intact groves along the base of the valley. Most significant sized trees in this grove are in the 1.75 to 2 meter dbh range. The vegetation in the area is fairly lush with a good layer of Devils Club, however with sandy soil and areas that show evidence of frequent high water there are patches of more limited undergrowth. There is a fairly clear trail that runs from the Goldstream FSR to the tree and shows evidence of being used by both elk and people. A muddy, wetland area directly south of the tree shows evidence of being a well used elk bed.

access_notes: From Revelstoke take Highway 1 West.  At the junction 500m from west end of Revelstoke, turn north. Travel 6.5 km to Frisby FSR. Follow Frisby FSR North for 20k and take the west spur.  Go up the spur for 14 km. Walk 370m downhill off of the road,  initially through the 20 year old clearcut.
tree_site_notes: Slight split at base on S side and small hollow on N side. Located in Cedar/Hemlock grove with 15+ western red cedar @1-2.25 m DBH western red cedar.  Slightly turreted with one side of canopy quite defoliated.  High productivity, moisture collecting flat area near creek, devil's club, western yew, wild ginger, ferns on overall E facing moderate mid slope. Tree is at base of moderate slope coming into the flat area. Within planned cutblock boundary and OGMA.

access_notes: Located beside the hydro transmission right of way clearing that crosses over the Elk River just upstream of where Morrissey Creek ties into the river.
tree_site_notes: Tree has a heavy lean and thickly covered in Gold Dust lichen.  Old Yeller is located in a wonderful setting amongst many very large cedars, cottonwoods, and the Jeffy Dougy fir.

access_notes: Heading west from Creston on Highway 3 a parking lot on the right, just before the Summit Creek bridge is the starting point.
tree_site_notes: The Kootenay River has flooded these lowlands repeatedly over the lifespan of these big cedars that now languish in the well maintained grasses of a once established campground. The tree is estimated to be over 800 years.

access_notes: Travel Akokalyx FSR to 12.5 km then turn south on Crawford FSR. 1.5 km on south side of road at small pullout. walk in 20 m.
tree_site_notes: Straight very slightly slanted tree with some twisted branch turreting midway up. Flat area to gently S facing sloped area 50 m from Akokalyx river. Very lush with large Devil's Club. Small remnant grove (<1 hectare) between fsr and river. Road less than 20 m away. Largest cedar in a grove of 8 other significant western red cedar (above 1.5 m) within 50m including a set of twins over 2m dbh each.

access_notes: From Highway 3, when travelling west from Creston over Kootenay Pass, a parking area on the left just before the avalanche road closure gate is the trailhead.
tree_site_notes: The tree in Ralph’s Grove is just one of many amazing trees nestled in the sheltered hollow of Summit Creek. This tree stands out, as it is definitely the largest cedar that is visible from the trail.

access_notes: Driving Directions:From Bull River, travel north on the Wardner Fort Steele Road. Turn east on Bull River Road. In 8.5km the road intersects with Bull River FSR. Turn left (northeast) on Bull River FSR. The trailhead is approximately 10km from this junction, on the left, at a pullout just past the Dibble Cr bridge.  The trail follows a deactivated road for about 3km.  Then steeper single track for 1km to a tributary and the old growth cedar stands starting at about 1260m elev. along the east side of the creek.  The measured cedar is at about 5km, above the trail, just before the first slide path.
tree_site_notes: The measured tree is touching another large cedar at the base.  Both trees have forked stems at 3-5m.  The fork on the measured tree is dead.  This patch of trees contains several cedars in the 150-170cm range. This cedar old growth is, for now, fed by Dibble Glacier and is quite unique in the East Kootenay area.

access_notes: Driving from Kimberley, take the St. Mary's Lake Rd, which eventually turns into the St. Mary's River Rd after the lake is passed. Continue following the St. Mary's River Rd past the Redding Creek Rd. The tree is about 150m before Pyramid Creek on the North side of the road. The tall candelabra top of the tree should be noticeable, along with 3 others in close proximity.
tree_site_notes: Dead candelabra top. No noticeable damage to the tree, but it is leaning slightly.

access_notes: The trail is accessed from the 2nd Island Lake parking lot in summer. Follow the Old Growth Trail to the Cabin Ridge junction (signed). Trail descends down to Lizard Creek, where a sometimes tenuous crossing is required. This big Cedar is just up the trail aways, but not right beside the trail.
tree_site_notes: Located right beside the trail, with a big burl overhanging you as you pass by, it is difficult to miss. The added Grizzly handle is because this game trail is the grizzly bears path when it traverses from Hunter Bowl to Cabin Bowl.

access_notes: Orca Road is an old skid trail that traverses at the base of the Lizard Range. A bridge crossing Lizard Creek, just upstream of the sawdust pile meadow in Cedar Valley is the trailhead. This tree is located on the downside of the road about 750 m after crossing the creek.
tree_site_notes: The Whale is a massive beast. With its wall of wood confronting you in the dark ocean of this forest. It gets its name from the Orca Rock peak whose fin sticks out of the sea of powder above, and is visible on the many horizons of the Lizard Range.

The trail is accessed by an old road on the south side of Highway 16, 1/2km before the Goat River bridge and rest area. The old road is easily missed by those driving on Highway 16, because of the steep drop it takes off the highway. If you do not have a 4-WD vehicle, it is best to park at the Goat River rest area and walk west on the south side of Highway 16 to spot the rough access road. If you drive down the old road, there is a small clearing a short ways down with room to park.The hike initially follows the old road. You will cross a rough wooden bridge over a creek. Shortly afterwards, you will reach a fork in the road where the right side is very overgrown. Take the left fork. A short distance after this, there is a second fork in the road, where an ATV trail continues to the right and the left side appears less worn-in. At this second fork, follow the left (less worn-in) side. After a minute or so, take the trail on the left leading away from the old road and into the forest (it should be flagged). From here, the trail is easy to follow. You will stay on the plateau before crossing a stream and descending towards the canyon. After the stream is where the very old trees are located.GPS Coordinates:- Old road off Highway 16: 53.4924063, -120.6176087- Goat River Canyon (trail end point, for reference, to ensure one is hiking in the correct direction): 53.4772961, -120.6406700.

access_notes: Drive east 110 km (ca. 1 hour) from Prince George to the Ancient Forest/Chun T'oh Whudujut Provincial Park trail parking lot (marking with highway pullout signs). From the Ancient Forest trail pullout drive west 5 km to the entry site for the Ministry of Transport quarry, found on the south side of the road (look for locked gate on access road).  Park on the roadside or on the edge of the quarry pull-off and hike up the old Driscoll Ridge trail. The trail is heavily overgrown with Devil's Club and alder, watch for the red trail markers on trees (the old trail route also shows on most GPS map apps).  If the lower quarry site is active access on the old Driscoll Ridge trail is not allowed.
tree_site_notes: The stand is located on level mid-slope bench on the north face of Driscoll Ridge. Trees are growing on a wet site with ground vegetation dominated by Devil's Club, located in the ICHvk2 biogeoclimatic zone. The tree is healthy with abundant "wolf-tree" (downward sweeping) branches in the lower canopy. The broken top is consistent with nearly all the old trees on this site.

Turn onto Blanket FSR. The road climbs up above Greenbush Lake, and the tree is just below the road after the  first switchback.
tree_site_notes: This tree stands out amongst the surrounding forest. Both the height, and shadowy girth are very impressive. The tree had a blue "O" spray painted on the trunk. This mark indicated that I was not the first person to visit this tree. The follow up search revealed that a forester with Tolko had marked this tree 12 years earlier.  LiDar imagery provided by Tolko (available if requested) showed this tree poking out of the data.

A post mounted solar panel on your right is your indicator to begin slowing down, where the Murphy Creek FSR is next on your right. A large timber frame sign, lets you know you are in the right location. Following the road a short distance, take the right turn at the fork where after about 500 m. through a recent approx. 20 year old cutblock, is the trailhead parking area.
tree_site_notes: Very healthy looking tree, with evidence of a strong cone crop being dispersed around the trees base. No signs of dead/blister rust affected trees in the vicinity. This small reserve is basically surrounded by logging blocks.

tree_site_notes: Given this tree's geographic location, low elevation, and indentifiable features (see photos of cones), it is most likely a white spruce (Picea glauca). Engelmann spruce is found at higher elevations in this region though hybridization is possible. This tree is found on a slope just above a wet area containing large western red cedars in the Interior Cedar Hemlock BEC zone. The tree is healthy with no broken top or obvious signs of rot. Aspect is roughly south though I forgot to take a reading. Surrounding vegetation includes Ribes, devil's club, queen's cup, western hemlock, and western red-cedar.

The site can be accessed by driving east on Highway #3 from the Highway #43 traffic lights in Sparwood for 11km. to the Coal Mountain /Michel Creek Road. This paved road continues for 22.6 km. to the Coal Mountain mine gate, where the Flathead FSR to the right leads to the next right turn-off at 4.4 km.. A new logging road and bridge have been built crossing Michel Creek, where you can either begin walking here, or continue on a very rough road for 800 m. to the trailhead. The unmarked old road on the west side of the landing is your route. After hiking for 2.5 km. you will come to an intersection. The left trail/road leads to Barnes Lake, while the right road climbs steeply up to Elliot Lake. If heading to Barnes Lake the trail continues for an additional 1.3 km. following along a beautiful alpine meadow, to where you will arrive at the south campsite.
The Whitebark Pine that was sampled, is located just beside the campsite.
tree_site_notes: Many dead standing whitebark pines in this vicinity. Likely blister rust casualties. The remaining live trees appear to be somewhat healthy. Cores from tree were solid to the center. Trees estimated age is 350 years old. +/- 50 yrs.

access_notes: This tree was located near Crystal Lake in North Tweedsmuir Provincial Park. To access the site requires a 1 hour float plane ride from Burns Lake BC, followed by a 1 hour power boat trip to the north end of Tesla lake. This site required a 1 km hike from the shore of the lake.
tree_site_notes: This whitebark pine was living and had no signs of blister rust, ips, blue stain fungus or mountain pine beetle present. It was a single stem and dominant in the canopy with 5-6 other whitebark pine trees in good health. A bear was using the base of one of the trees as a wallow and a squirrel midden were also present in this dominant cohort. It was situated in a productive toe slope near a riparian area in a cool and moist site with strong coastal influences. Four increment cores were taken with a haglof borer to determine the age of the tree. The 24 inch increment borer was not long enough to obtain the exact age of the tree. The minimum age of the tree (as determined through tree ring measurements of the four samples) is 459 years (1561-2020). Pith estimates could not be used to estimate the location of the centre of the tree as no ring curvature was present. The absence of ring curvature, DBH of the tree, and calculation of years to reach coring height suggest that this tree is between 600-800 years in age. The tree is estimated to be 20m tall with a basal DBH of 0.9m.
